thread.title: Hurricane Katrina: Then and now
thread.title_full: Hurricane Katrina: Then and now - MarketWatch

author: MarketWatch
title: Hurricane Katrina: Then and now
text:
Mario Tama/Getty Images Slide 1 of 13 Ten years ago the world saw images of New Orleans awash in floodwaters in the wake of Hurricane Katrina, which killed at least 1,836 people and is considered the costliest natural disaster in U.S. history. Devastation was widespread throughout the city, with floodwaters as high as 12 feet in some areas. Thousands were left homeless in Louisiana, Mississippi, Alabama and Florida by the storm. The 10th anniversary of Hurricane Katrina is Aug. 29. Above, on Aug. 31, 2005, two days after the storm hit the city, two men paddle in high water near the Claiborne Bridge in the Lower Ninth Ward.
Mario Tama/Getty Images Slide 2 of 13 Ten years later, in the same location, a school bus drops off a student in front of the Claiborne Bridge in the Lower Ninth Ward May 12 in New Orleans. The area remains largely uninhabited.
Mario Tama/Getty Images Slide 3 of 13 Robert Fontaine walks past a burning house fire in New Orleans’ Seventh Ward Sept. 6, 2005.
Mario Tama/Getty Images Slide 4 of 13 Nearly 10 years later, houses stand in the same Seventh Ward location in May of this year.
Mario Tama/Getty Images Slide 5 of 13 A group of Amish student volunteers tour the devastated Ninth Ward Feb. 24, 2006 in New Orleans, six months after the storm.
Mario Tama/Getty Images Slide 6 of 13 Today, new homes stand in the development built by the Make it Right Foundation for residents whose homes were destroyed.
Mario Tama/Getty Images Slide 7 of 13 June 10, 2007: Residents of the B.W. Cooper housing project in New Orleans practice flips using mattresses two years after the storm. Before Hurricane Katrina, B.W. Cooper held about 1,000 families and was the city’s largest housing project, but ended up more than 80% empty. About 10,000 public housing residents in New Orleans were unable to return to their apartments because of storm damage. The U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development decided to tear down B.W. Cooper and other major New Orleans housing projects and replace them with mixed income developments.
Mario Tama/Getty Images Slide 8 of 13 In May of this year, rubble remains at the site of where the B.W. Cooper housing projects stood, The low-income housing development will eventually be replaced by two-story, townhouse-style buildings. The city has revamped its major housing projects following Katrina.
Mario Tama/Getty Images Slide 9 of 13 Workers in 2006 rebuild the levee which was breached by Hurricane Katrina along the Industrial Canal in the city’s Lower Ninth Ward.
Mario Tama/Getty Images Slide 10 of 13 New homes stand along the rebuilt Industrial Canal levee in this May photo.
Mario Tama/Getty Images Slide 11 of 13 Water floods an aboveground cemetery outside St. Patrick’s Church in Plaquemines Parish in September, 2005 in Port Sulphur, La., nearly two weeks after the storm.
Mario Tama/Getty Images Slide 12 of 13 The same cemetery outside St. Patrick’s Church in May.
Mario Tama/Getty Images Slide 13 of 13 The same cemetery outside St. Patrick’s Church in May.
